sen.j: 大仏様（だいぶつよう）は、日本の伝統的な寺院建築の様式の一つ。
sen.e: Daubutsu-yo is one of the traditional temple architectural styles in Japan.
Daubutsu-yo is one of the traditional temple architectural styles in Japan.
Daubutsu-yo is one of the traditional temple architectural styles in Japan.

sen.j: 和様・禅宗様に対する言葉。
sen.e: It is different from the 'wa-yo' and 'zenshu-yo' styles.
It is different from the 'wa-yo' and 'zenshu-yo' styles.
It is different from the 'wa-yo' (Japanese style) and 'zenshu-yo' (Zen Sect style).
sen.cmt: wa-yo, zenshu-yoの補足を加えるため文章を一部修正

sen.j: 仏像を指す「大仏様（だいぶつさま）」は大仏を参照。
sen.e: For the Buddha statue known as 'Daibutsu-sama', please refer to 'Daibutsu'.
For the Buddha statue known as 'Daibutsu-sama', please refer to 'Daibutsu'.
For the Buddha statue known as 'Daibutsu-sama', please refer to 'Daibutsu'.

sen.j: 6世紀から8世紀にかけて日本の飛鳥時代・奈良時代には遣隋使・遣唐使により中国から伝えられた建築様式は、平安時代を経て日本化し、柱を細く、天井を低めにした穏やかな空間が好まれるようになった。
sen.e: The Chinese architectural style brought to Japan between the 6th and 8th century by Japanese envoys to Sui and Tang Dynasty China became Japanized during the Heian period, and calm spaces with slim columns and low ceilings came into favor.

The Chinese architectural style brought to Japan between the 6th and 8th century by Japanese envoys to Sui and Tang Dynasty China became Japanized during the Heian period, and calm spaces with slim columns and low ceilings came into favor.

The Chinese architectural style brought to Japan between the 6th and 8th century during the Asuka and Nara periods by Japanese envoys to Sui and Tang Dynasty China became Japanized during the Heian period, and calm spaces with slim columns and low ceilings came into favor.
sen.cmt: 「飛鳥時代・奈良時代」を訳出しました。

sen.j: 平安時代以降には日本独自の形態として発展し、この建築様式を和様と呼ぶ。
sen.e: This developed into a uniquely Japanese style following the Heian period to become what is known as the 'Wa-yo' architectural style.
This developed into a uniquely Japanese style following the Heian period to become what is known as the 'Wa-yo' architectural style.
This developed into a uniquely Japanese style following the Heian period to become what is known as the 'Wa-yo' architectural style.

sen.j: 平安時代後期になると、平清盛の神戸港対外開港など中国（宋）との交易が活発になったことで、再び中国の建築様式が伝えられた。
sen.e: During the latter part of the Heian period, trade with China (Song) flourished due to policies such as TAIRA no Kiyomori's opening of Kobe Port to foreign countries, and Japan was once again exposed to China's architectural style.

During the latter part of the Heian period, trade with China (Song) flourished due to policies such as TAIRA no Kiyomori's opening of Kobe Port to foreign countries, and Japan was once again exposed to China's architectural style.

During the latter part of the Heian period, trade with China (Song) flourished due to policies such as TAIRA no Kiyomori's opening of Kobe Port to foreign countries, and Japan was once again exposed to China's architectural style.

sen.j: まず入ってきたのは東大寺再興の際に用いられた様式で、もとは天竺様と呼ばれたが、第二次世界大戦後になって大仏様という用語が、太田博太郎らによって提唱された。
sen.e: The first to enter was the style used during the restoration of Todai-ji Temple, which was known as 'tenjiku-yo', but the alternative term 'daibutsu-yo' was proposed by Hakutaro OTA in the postwar period.

The first to enter was the style used during the restoration of Todai-ji Temple, which was known as 'tenjiku-yo', but the alternative term 'daibutsu-yo' was proposed by Hakutaro OTA in the postwar period.

The first to enter was the style used during the restoration of Todai-ji Temple, which was known as 'tenjiku-yo', but the alternative term 'daibutsu-yo' was proposed by Hakutaro OTA in the postwar period.

sen.j: 天平時代に建設された東大寺東大寺盧舎那仏像は平安時代末期の治承・寿永の乱の中、焼失した。
sen.e: The Tempyo era statue of Rushana at Todai-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Genpei War at the end of the Heian period.
The Tempyo era statue of Rushana at Todai-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Genpei War at the end of the Heian period.
The Tenpyo era statue of Rushana at Todai-ji Temple was destroyed by fire during the Genpei War at the end of the Heian period.

sen.j: 俊乗坊重源は幾多の困難を克服して大仏を鋳造し、1185年、開眼供養。
sen.e: Chogen Shunjobo overcame numerous difficulties to cast a Great Buddha statue, for which the consecration ceremony was held in 1185.
Chogen Shunjobo overcame numerous difficulties to cast a Great Buddha statue, for which the consecration ceremony was held in 1185.
Shunjobo Chogen overcame numerous difficulties to cast a Great Buddha statue, for which the consecration ceremony was held in 1185.

sen.j: 1195年、大仏殿を再建。
sen.e: The Great Buddha statue hall was rebuilt in 1195.
The Great Buddha statue hall was rebuilt in 1195.
The Great Buddha statue hall was rebuilt in 1195.

sen.j: 1203年に総供養を行った（東大寺盧舎那仏像を参照）。
sen.e: The offering was made in 1203 (please refer to 'Todai-ji Temple Rushana statue').
The offering was made in 1203 (please refer to 'Todai-ji Temple Rushana statue').
The offering was made in 1203 (please refer to 'Todai-ji Temple Rushana statue').

sen.j: 重源が再建した大仏殿などの建築様式は非常に独特なもので、当時の中国（宋）の福建省周辺の建築様式に通じるといわれている。
sen.e: The architectural style in which Chogen restored buildings including the Great Buddha hall was highly unique and is said to have been similar to the contemporary style of China's (Song) Fujian Province.

The architectural style in which Chogen restored buildings including the Great Buddha hall was highly unique and is said to have been similar to the contemporary style of China's (Song) Fujian Province.

The architectural style in which Chogen restored buildings including the Great Buddha hall was highly unique and is said to have been similar to the contemporary style of China's (Song) Fujian Province.

sen.j: その建築様式は合理的な構造、豪放な意匠で大仏殿にはふさわしいものであったが、日本人の好む穏やかな空間とは相容れない面もあり、重源が死去すると大仏様も衰えた。
sen.e: The architectural style is practical in structure and bold in design, which was ideally suited for housing the Great Buddha statue, but there were aspects that conflicted with the Japanese fondness of gentle spaces, and the daibutsu-yo style went into decline following Chogen's death.

The architectural style is practical in structure and bold in design, which was ideally suited for housing the Great Buddha statue, but there were aspects that conflicted with the Japanese fondness of gentle spaces, and the daibutsu-yo style went into decline following Chogen's death.

The architectural style is practical in structure and bold in design, which was ideally suited for housing the Great Buddha statue, but there were aspects that conflicted with the Japanese fondness of gentle spaces, and the daibutsu-yo style went into decline following Chogen's death.

sen.j: 大仏殿再建に関わった職人は各地へ移り、大仏様の影響を受けた和様も生まれ、これを折衷様と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The craftsmen involved in the restoration of the Great Buddha hall spread throughout the country and a form of daibutsu-yo-influenced wa-yo, known as 'setchuu-yo', was born.
The craftsmen involved in the restoration of the Great Buddha hall spread throughout the country and a form of daibutsu-yo-influenced wa-yo, known as 'setchuu-yo', was born.
The craftsmen involved in the restoration of the Great Buddha hall spread throughout the country and a form of daibutsu-yo-influenced wa-yo, known as 'setchu-yo', was born.

sen.j: その後、禅僧が活発に往来し、中国の寺院建築様式が伝えられた。
sen.e: Following this, the Chinese temple architectural style made its way to Japan due to the great movement of Zen monks between China and Japan.
Following this, the Chinese temple architectural style made its way to Japan due to the great movement of Zen monks between China and Japan.
Following this, the Chinese temple architectural style made its way to Japan due to the great movement of Zen monks between China and Japan.

sen.j: これは禅宗寺院の仏堂に多く用いられ、江戸時代から唐様と呼ばれたが、第二次世界大戦後になって禅宗様という用語が提唱された。
sen.e: This style, often used in Buddha statue halls of Zen Sect temples, had been called 'kara-yo' since the Edo period, but the term 'zenshu-yo' was proposed following the end of the Second World War.
This style, often used in Buddha statue halls of Zen Sect temples, had been called 'kara-yo' since the Edo period, but the term 'zenshu-yo' was proposed following the end of the Second World War.
This style, often used in Buddha statue halls of Zen Sect temples, had been called 'kara-yo' since the Edo period, but the term 'zenshu-yo' was proposed following the end of the Second World War.

sen.j: 一部は禅宗様（唐様）の特徴にも通じる。
sen.e: Has some elements in common with zenshu-yo (kara-yo).
Has some elements in common with zenshu-yo (kara-yo).
Has some elements in common with zenshu-yo (kara-yo).

sen.j: 構造的には、貫 (建築)といわれる水平方向の材を使い、柱と強固に組み合わせて構造を強化している
sen.e: Architecturally it utilizes horizontal wooden beams known as penetrating tie beams which are combined with pillars to reinforce the structure
Architecturally it utilizes horizontal wooden beams known as penetrating tie beams which are combined with pillars to reinforce the structure
Architecturally it utilizes horizontal wooden beams known as penetrating tie beams which are combined with pillars to reinforce the structure

sen.j: 貫の先端には繰り型（くりがた）といわれる装飾を付けている
sen.e: The wooden nosings (kibana) at the ends of penetrating tie beams are decorated with moldings known as 'kurigata'.
The wooden nosings (kibana) at the ends of penetrating tie beams are decorated with moldings known as 'kurigata'.
The ends of penetrating tie beams are decorated with moldings known as 'kurigata'.
sen.cmt: The wooden nosings (kibana)の表現は原文にないため除きました。

sen.j: 挿肘木（さしひじき）と呼ばれる独特の組物を用いる。
sen.e: Use of a unique bracket complex known as 'sashihijiki' (bracket arms inserted into the shaft of a pillar).
Use of a unique bracket complex known as 'sashihijiki' (bracket arms inserted into the shaft of a pillar).
Use of a unique bracket complex known as 'sashihijiki' (bracket arms inserted into the shaft of a pillar).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを半角にしました。

sen.j: 和様・禅宗様では柱の上に組物を置くが、柱の途中に差し込むように組物を付ける
sen.e: Both wa-yo and zenshu-yo incorporate complexes placed on top of pillars but achieve this using bracket complexes inserted partway up the pillar.
Both wa-yo and zenshu-yo incorporate complexes placed on top of pillars but achieve this using bracket complexes inserted partway up the pillar.
Both wa-yo and zenshu-yo incorporate complexes placed on top of pillars but achieve this using bracket complexes inserted partway up the pillar,
sen.cmt: 文末が後の「など」につながるため、ピリオドをカンマに変更

sen.j: など
sen.e: Etc.
Etc.
etc.

sen.j: 大工の伝承では、和様・天竺様・唐様の区別がなされ、明治時代以降の建築史で使用されてきており大仏様の呼称は存在しなかった。
sen.e: Carpenters had traditionally classified temple architectural styles as wa-yo (Japanese style), tenjiku-yo (Indian style) and kara-yo (Chinese style), and these classifications continued to be used in architectural histories after the Meiji period with no concept of daibutsu-yo.

Carpenters had traditionally classified temple architectural styles as wa-yo (Japanese style), tenjiku-yo (Indian style) and kara-yo (Chinese style), and these classifications continued to be used in architectural histories after the Meiji period with no concept of daibutsu-yo.

Carpenters had traditionally classified temple architectural styles as wa-yo (Japanese style), tenjiku-yo (Indian style) and kara-yo (Chinese style), and these classifications continued to be used in architectural histories after the Meiji period with no concept of daibutsu-yo.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、日本建築史家の太田博太郎（元、東京大学教授）が天竺様という名称を批判し「天竺はインドを意味し、天竺様ではインドの建築様式と誤解されてしまう。
sen.e: After the Second World War, Japanese architectural historian Hakutaro OTA (formerly a Professor at the University of Tokyo) criticized the term tenjiku-yo by stating that 'The fact that "Tenjiku~ means "India" leads the misunderstanding that "tenjiku-yo" refers to an Indian architectural style.

After the Second World War, Japanese architectural historian Hakutaro OTA (formerly a Professor at the University of Tokyo) criticized the term tenjiku-yo by stating that 'The fact that "Tenjiku~ means "India", and leads the misunderstanding that "tenjiku-yo" refers to an Indian architectural style.

After the Second World War, Japanese architectural historian Hakutaro OTA (formerly a Professor at the University of Tokyo) criticized the term tenjiku-yo by stating that 'The fact that "Tenjiku" means "India", and leads the misunderstanding that "tenjiku-yo" refers to an Indian architectural style.

sen.j: 元来が大仏殿の復興に使われた時に用いられたので大仏様と呼ぶべきである。
sen.e: It was utilized when rebuilding Great Buddha Halls and should therefore be referred to as "daibutsu-yo".
It was utilized when rebuilding Great Buddha Halls and should therefore be referred to as "daibutsu-yo".
It was utilized when rebuilding Great Buddha Halls and should therefore be referred to as "daibutsu-yo".

sen.j: また、唐様は禅宗寺院に使われたので、禅宗様と呼ぶべき」という趣旨の提案を行った。
sen.e: Kara-yo was used in the construction of Zen temples and should therefore be referred to as "zenshu-yo".'
Kara-yo was used in the construction of Zen temples and should therefore be referred to as "zenshu-yo".'
Kara-yo was used in the construction of Zen temples and should therefore be referred to as "zenshu-yo".'

sen.j: 次第に天竺様は大仏様に代わり、現在の建築史では一般的に和様・大仏様・禅宗様と使われている。
sen.e: The term 'tenjiku-yo' gradually gave way to 'daibutsu-yo', and current architectural histories generally use the terms 'wa-yo', 'daibutsu-yo' and 'zenshu-yo'.
The term 'tenjiku-yo' gradually gave way to 'daibutsu-yo', and current architectural histories generally use the terms 'wa-yo', 'daibutsu-yo' and 'zenshu-yo'.
The term 'tenjiku-yo' gradually gave way to 'daibutsu-yo', and current architectural histories generally use the terms 'wa-yo', 'daibutsu-yo' and 'zenshu-yo'.

sen.j: （歴史教科書などでは、天竺様・唐様という呼び方も使われている）
sen.e: Although history textbooks also use the terms 'tenjiku-yo' and 'kara-yo'.
Although history textbooks also use the terms 'tenjiku-yo' and 'kara-yo'.
Although history textbooks also use the terms 'tenjiku-yo' and 'kara-yo'.

sen.j: しかし、大仏様という呼び方もまた聖武天皇が創建した奈良時代の大仏殿の様式と誤解されたり、禅宗様の様式は（特に近世以降）禅宗以外の真言宗や日蓮宗の寺院でも用られることが少なくなく、かえって誤解を生じる面がある。
sen.e: However, there are further sources of confusion as the term 'daibutsu-yo' is also mistaken for the Great Buddha hall style created by Emperor Shomu during the Nara period, and it is also not rare for the 'zenshu-yo' style to be used in temples of Buddhist sects other Zen (particularly since modern times), including the Shingon and Nichiren Sects.

However, there are further sources of confusion as the term 'daibutsu-yo' is also mistaken for the Great Buddha hall style created by Emperor Shomu during the Nara period, and it is also not rare for the 'zenshu-yo' style to be used in temples of Buddhist sects other Zen (particularly since modern times), including the Shingon and Nichiren Sects.

However, there are further sources of confusion as the term 'daibutsu-yo' is also mistaken for the Great Buddha hall style created by Emperor Shomu during the Nara period, and it is also not rare for the 'zenshu-yo' style to be used in temples of Buddhist sects other than Zen (particularly since modern times), including the Shingon and Nichiren Sects.
sen.cmt: Buddhist sects other Zen→Buddhist sects other than Zenに修正

sen.j: 東大寺南大門、開山堂、法華堂礼堂 俊乗坊重源時代の遺構
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple: Nandai-mon gate, Kaizan-do, Hokke-do Rai-do (meditation hall), remains from the time of Chogen SHUNJYOBO.
Todai-ji Temple: Nandai-mon gate, Kaizan-do, Hokke-do Rai-do (meditation hall), remains from the time of Chogen SHUNJYOBO.
Todai-ji Temple: Nandai-mon gate (great south gate), Kaisan-do hall (founder's hall), Rai-do (meditation hall) of the Hokke-do hall (Lotus hall), remains from the time of Shunjobo Chogen.
sen.cmt: Shunjobo Chogen、Kaizen-do→Kaisan-do hall、Hokke-do Rai-do→Rai-do of the Hokke-do hallとし、それぞれ補足を入れました。

sen.j: 浄土寺 (小野市)浄土堂（兵庫県小野市、国宝） 1197年築、重源時代の遺構

sen.cmt: "Chogen Shunjobo"を削除し、Chogenのみとしました。

sen.j: 醍醐寺経蔵 1195年俊乗坊重源が建立。
sen.e: Scripture house of Daigo-ji Temple: Constructed in 1195 by Chogen Chogen Shunjobo.

sen.cmt: 語順をShunjobo Chogenとし、Chogenの重複分を削除しました。

sen.e: Destroyed by fire in 1939.

sen.j: 東大寺大仏殿 江戸時代の再建であるが、大仏様の雰囲気を伝えている
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple Great Buddha hall: Constructed during the Edo period but maintains a daibutsu-yo look.

sen.j: 首里城守礼門 1945年沖縄戦で焼失。
